Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Digital Behavioral Pain Management Intervention in Orthopedic Trauma Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to MSS or HE using the REDCap system with a 1:1 ratio.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults aged 18-80 undergoing orthopedic trauma surgery.

Intervention.evidence: digital behavioral pain management intervention, "My Surgical Success" (MSS), compared to a digital general health education (HE) intervention

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the feasibility and efficacy of a digital behavioral pain management intervention

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was feasibility, assessed by treatment acceptability and engagement rate, measured up to 3 months post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to MSS or HE using the REDCap system with a 1:1 ratio.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 84 participants were randomised (MSS, n = 37; HE, n = 47) between December 2018 and January 2020.

Result_Outcome.evidence: MSS participants showed greater reductions in pain intensity over time (F[215] = 5.23; P = .024).
